Now the the Times has exposed this dirty little secret, how about looking into a few other closets full of skeletons?
1.) There is no data to substantiate that EMR's improve care
2.) Many hospitals have now changed systems multiple times. In order for a physician to access their patients test results and reports, they have to change their systems to the hospital's system. Each change costs private physicians anywhere from $20,000-$50,000 from which the hospital most assuredly gets its cut.
3.) There is a time proven EMR system that is free. It has been in use by the VA. Almost no hospitals use this system
4.) EMR systems don't communicate with each other. ergo the only people benefitting from EMR's are hospitals and EMR software companies and their techs.
5.) It is virtually impossible for a physician to have a part time primary care practice as the overhead is too onerous.
6.) If a physician leaves medical practice for two yrs in many states they are required to take a horrendously expensive unproven test to qualify to resume practice.
7.) There is no viable way for physicians who have taken longer leaves to obtain clinical refreshers. Drexel offers the option in 3 modules of $8500 each. That is $25500 plus room and board and expenses. That exceeds medical school tuition in many states.
8) Each insurance company has different preapproval mandates and formularies the physicians must comply with.

Is there any wonder why there is a physician shortage and early retirement?

I don't disagree with you but I think you need to draw a distinction between HMO's that are for-profit and those few, like Kaiser or Group Health, which are structured as non-profit entities.  As a Kaiser member and former employee for 30 years, I have never seen or experienced any poor care that I thought was due to monetary concerns.  There are pressures on providers to see patients and to provide cost-effective care but I think we all want cost-effective care; otherwise, as we currently see, costs spiral out of control.  I'd like to see a single payer system but I'd like to see that system reimbursing capititated care rather than fee-for-service.  Hilary Clinton's plan back in the early '90's would be a good starting point for designing a system.

FINALLY! Someone brought up the real solution. Single Payer system...which throws the GOP into apoplectic fits because it seems so "socialist - heaven forbid. We have socialist education, and that seems to provide pretty well, despite its downward spiral in quality in recent years.  And socialism cohabits pretty well with democracy.  The fear comes from super-capitalists who fear that if there is not a great divide between the ultra-rich and the peons, that their sheltered world may be tarnished.  The ether-air that they inhale (remember the recent election with the republicans in their factual bubble) can only see the economic gain...not the quality and efficiency of a system that might not line their pockets in gold as quickly as the current system. By the way, in most major US cities, the largest buildings are owned and named by insurance companies and banks.  Doesn't that tell you about our society as a whole?  A glimmer of light - I actually had a veterinarian who made house calls, and when my pet died despite the fact that he had called me to tell me an operation was a success, he felt so bad that he cremated her and brought me the ashes.  Would that our doctors for people had that kind of compassion and treatment ethic! It should NOT be about money. Shame on the pocketbooks that have determined how medicine should be practiced.

If the prevailing thought is that HMO's are well run, cost saving, and do not pressure or fire their MD's for not adhering to tacit or covert demands on their standards of practice then I suggest those persons google the name of the HMO plus "lawsuits". That can be an eye opener.

HMO good care may be given for ordinary circumstances; have a very complicated and potentially expensive condition and patient treatment options may change considerably.

There is constant inside pressure on HMO medical providers to keep costs down and "good statistics" on patient care up. Good statistics can include things such as how many patients are seen in an hour, how many hours a week are expected to be filled with returning clinical patients, how many hours were given to new patients, whether or not any patients were seen more times than generally dictated by the employer HMO. These are just some. There are definite consequences to the professional employee for failure to adhere to corporate expectations.

HMO's are corporations. They wield a considerable amount of power. There is little easy transparency for the general public as to the actual behavior of the HMO regarding patient, employee and professional issues.

Solution: I believe that we are in need of a single payer system to best care for all citizens. This is not universally popular but I have worked on both sides of our current systems; as a result I think it is the most visibly viable path for most of us.

This has zero to do with the Affordable Health Care Act, i.e. Obama. This process in Boise has been going on from well before the president was elected.  Everyone from individual practitioners to large hospital organizations and everything inbetween are taking advantage of every opportunity to maximize their revenues thru the perverse "free market" health care nightmare we've created. Until we shift reimbursement from fee for service to set payments for disease states as is done with DRGS in hospitalized Medicare patients and salary all practitioners including physicians the system will continue to be gamed. A single payer system would be the easiest way to move in this direction but sadly I don't see us moving in this direction. I work in health care and worked for the St. Luke's system for nearly 20 years. They provide outstanding care and aren't really trying to do anything St. Al's isn't. They've just been better at it. Until we as a country can reach a consensus that it would be for the good of all to change the perverse incentives we've created in our health system this is what we'll be stick with.

Our best bet to stabilize & ensure Social Security & Medicare/Medicaid funding well into the future would be to simultaneously (1) Permanently lower employee paid payroll tax rates (to 4%), with the difference made up by (2) Uncapping the current limit on wage & salary income subject to payroll tax, and (3) Introducing a $30/Metric Ton carbon tax, such tax rate to increase annually at the rate of inflation.

This payroll tax reform would broaden the SS/FICA/Medicaid tax base, while making the payroll tax less regressive.

The carbon tax would supplement the payroll tax base, while enhancing incentives for energy conservation, improved efficiency and investment in lower carbon renewable energy technologies.

You obviously have no idea what "Obama care" is.

There isn't a "socialist" bone in the Obamacare body, right wing propaganda notwithstanding.

Obamacare leaves ALL of the major players in place (including for profit health insurance companies, for profit hospital chains, etc.) and does absolutely nothing to change the overall structure of the health care "system".

Both entities then engaged in an arms race of practice acquisitions at increasingly ridiculous prices far in excess of fair market value all for the purpose of locking up market share. The creative ways of skirting FMV limits are mind boggling. 401Ks, 403bs, 457fs, inflated moving expenses even when no move was involved, huge sign on bonuses, months of PTO, double dipping speaker honoraria etc. Some employed docs in Boise are earning at the 99th percentile far above what docs in NY, LA or SF earn. You can't blame them. These CEOs came with a Brink's truck. The problem is, Boise is small city in a small population state and consumers are the ones getting hosed. The whole situation in Boise is a case study in anti-kickback violations. But the person who started it all is long gone earning seven figures somewhere else. Eventually the docs will pay the price when the bubble of inflated practice acquisition bursts.

This sounds more like a dream than a business model. Most BT users are not paying for a client, and there are so many free clients that I cannot see why anyone would pay for one. (I use Linux and the KDE desktop environment which comes with its own excellent BT client, KTorrent.) I recall the Azureus, now Vuze, developers tried to go down the path described in the article without much success.

This article also fails to distinguish between BitTorrent the company and the Internet protocol itself. As an open specification, the BT protocol doesn't belong to anybody. That's why any competent developer can write a BT client. No one needs BitTorrent the company for this.

The other part of a BT ecosystem are the "trackers." These are servers that do not contain any actual content themselves but coordinate the file sharing activities of the individual clients. The best known, or most notorious if you will, of these is The Pirate Bay, but there are literally thousands of other trackers all over the world. Once again BT the company has no monopoly here. Anyone can download the software required to set up a tracker.

So, again I ask, what is the business model here exactly?

The Affordable Care Act has absolutely nothing to do with the problems raised in this article.

Fee for service payment is the main problem. If hospitals own physician practices and if they make more money for doing "things" (like admitting patients, doing tests, doing surgery or procedures, etc.) then they will put pressure on their salaried physician employees to do whatever is necessary for them to make more money, just as any other employer would.

If the hospitals were operating in a full risk environment (like Kaiser), the incentives would be to do LESS, not more.

The only viable future for cost effective medicine in the US lies in fully integrated, non profit health care systems (like Kaiser) that assume full risk and who own their own insurance product. The primary incentive in such systems is in the direction of underutilization (completely the opposite of the current system.) To prevent this from becoming a pernicious incentive, competing systems would ultimately be selling their services based on outcome statistics and patient satisfaction statistics. If they failed to provide sufficient services to their patients to keep them healthy and happy they wouldn't be able to recruit patients into their system.

Your last paragraph is not accurate.

Everything depends on how things are being reimbursed.

If the fee for service model is in effect, your comments are basically correct.

If a full risk model is in effect (like Kaiser and certain others) then everything done to/for the patient becomes a cost and there is NO opportunity to make money by doing more "things".

And Medicare isn't the driving force behind any of this. Physicians are leaving small practices and joining larger groups (or even becoming salaried employees) because it isn't possible to earn a decent living in a small practice and the bureaucratic overhead in a small practice is overwhelming (largely due to the existence of multiple private insurance companies, each with their own unique billing requirements).
